questions.text: A 6 y/o child presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and a greyish membrane covering the tonsils. The doctor suspects diphtheria. Which diagnostic test is used for confirming the production of diphtheria toxin by C.diptheriae?
questions.explanation:
Test

Features

Elek’s gel precipitation test

gel precipitation test" data-author="" data-hash="9889" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/duP7wodTOR1trhtzKtWV1744446503.png" />
  • Immunodiffusion in gel.
  • The strain isolated is streaked onto a media containing a filter paper soaked with antitoxin.
  • If the strain is toxigenic, it liberates the toxin which diffuses in the agar and meets with the antitoxin to produce an arrow-shaped precipitation band.
  • Used to know the relatedness between the strains isolated during an outbreak.

Schicks test
  • Based on the ability of circulating antitoxin to neutralize the diphtheria toxin given intradermally
  • Indicates immunity or susceptibility to the disease.

Tissue culture test
  • The toxigenicity can be demonstrated by incorporating the strains in the agar overlay of cell culture monolayers.
  • The toxin produced diffuses into the cells below and causes lysis of the cells

PCR
  • Detection of Toxin gene (tox) has been developed to detect the presence of genes coding for the toxin, in clinical isolates

ELISA
  • Detect toxins from the patient's isolate using an antitoxin and enzyme-substrate system.

questions.text: A patient infected with Bacillus anthracis presents with severe oedema and systemic symptoms. Which combination of virulence factors is primarily responsible for these clinical manifestations?

options.label: B
options.text: Protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor

questions.correct_answer: B. Protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Protective antigen, edema factor, and lethal factor

Virulence Factor of Bacillus Anthracis

Capsule

Exotoxin
  • The capsule is composed of poly-D-glutamic acid, which is different from the polysaccharide capsules found in most other bacteria.
  • It protects against phagocytosis.
  • The capsule is encoded by a plasmid.
  • If this plasmid is lost, the strain will become avirulent.
  • It is composed of protective antigen (PA), oedema factor (EF), and lethal factor (LF).
  • These proteins are nontoxic individually but work together to cause harmful effects.
  • The genes encoding anthrax toxin are carried on a plasmid.
  • PA binds to cell receptors and forms a membrane channel, which allows for the entry of EF and LF into the cell.
  • EF is an adenylate cyclase that causes oedema.
  • LF, when combined with PA, forms a lethal toxin. Lethal toxin is a major virulence factor and is the cause of death in infected people and animal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ED with muscle stiffness and spasms. He injured himself with a deep puncture wound while gardening 2 weeks ago; the wound looks necrotic, and he hasn't had a tetanus shot. Lab receives tissue for testing. Which lab finding best indicates Clostridium tetani?

options.label: A
options.text: Gram-positive cocci with clusters and no spore formation on microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: Alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with no concentric swarming movement

options.label: C
options.text: Drumstick-shaped terminal spores with black colour and gas production in Robertson’s cooked meat broth

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid liquefaction of gelatin and no proteolytic reaction in Robertson’s cooked meat broth

questions.correct_answer: C. Drumstick-shaped terminal spores with black colour and gas production in Robertson’s cooked meat broth
questions.explanation:
DIAGNOSIS OF C. TETANI

Specimen
  • Necrotic Tissue

Microscope examination

 
  • Gram +ve Bacilli
  • Spores with Drumstick appearance- Terminal Spores (Option A ruled out)

Blood Agar
  • Alpha hemolysis is produced, which later develops into Beta hemolysis, due to the production of hemolysin (tetanolysin).
  • Concentric movement is seen- Swarming Growth (Option B ruled out)

Robertson's Cooked Meat Broth


 
  • Black colour, gas production
  • Proteolytic reaction (Option D ruled out)

Gelatin stab
  • Fir tree appearance
  • Slow liquefaction

Fildes Technique
  • To obtain pure colonies of C. tetani
  • A test tube is filled with Nutrient broth, and pure colonies can be isolated from the surface.

questions.text: A 65 y/o female presents with severe diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and fever. She has been on clindamycin for the past 10 days to treat a dental infection. O/E, her colonoscopy reveals microabscesses. Stool samples are sent for further testing. Which diagnostic method is considered the gold standard for confirming the suspected infection?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

1. Colonoscopy
  • Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses.
  • Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis. (Option A ruled out)

 

2. Culture
  • Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection. (Option B ruled out)

3. Toxin Detection
  • ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard.
  • Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin.

4. Molecular Methods
  • PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples.

5. Histopathology
  • This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains
  • Highly specific but low sensitivity (Option D ruled out)

Treatment

Antibiotic Discontinuation
  • Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Oral vancomycin or metronidazole.
  • Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas.

Prevention

Antibiotic Stewardship
  • Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora.

Infection Control Measures
  • Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings.

Recent Treatment Option

Fecal Transplants
  • Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with a persistent cough with blood in sputum, fever, and weight loss. The chest X-ray shows infiltrates in the upper lobes. The clinician wants a rapid and reliable test for diagnosing. Which of the following statements about the GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It can detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance within 2 hours

options.label: B
options.text: It can differentiate between M. tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM)

options.label: C
options.text: It requires a biosafety level 3 laboratory for processing

options.label: D
options.text: It has low sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples

questions.correct_answer: A. It can detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance within 2 hours
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Rapid results: Provides results in about 2 hours
  • ↳ Simultaneous detection of M. tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance
  • ↳ High specificity: >99% specific for M. tuberculosis complex
  • ↳ Minimal biosafety requirements: Can be used outside of reference laboratories
  • ↳ Automated interpretation: Reduces operator-dependent errors
  • ↳ It can differentiate between M. tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) (Option B): While the GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is highly specific for the M. tuberculosis complex, it cannot differentiate between M. tuberculosis and other members of the complex, nor can it identify NTM. This option is incorrect.

  • ↳ It requires a biosafety level 3 laboratory for processing (Option C):
  • ↳ It has low sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples (Option D): While the sensitivity of GeneXpert is higher in smear-positive samples, it still maintains good sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples (60-80%), outperforming smear microscopy. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which type of leprosy is most likely affecting a patient who presents with localized, well-defined skin lesions and minimal bacterial presence?
questions.explanation:
Type

Characteristics

Lepromatous Leprosy

Low host resistance, abundant bacilli in lesions, widespread lesions, higher transmission likelihood (Option B ruled out).

Tuberculoid Leprosy

High resistance, limited well-defined skin lesions, minimal bacilli in the lesions (Option A).

Dimorphous (Borderline)

Characteristics of both lepromatous and tuberculoid forms, potential to shift between the two (Option C ruled out).

Indeterminate Leprosy

Early, unstable stage, may resolve spontaneously or progress to other forms (Option D ruled out).
